bibl.title: Letter from [Louise Young Kean] and Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 18, 1900

div1.p: The Keans discuss social events among the army personnel and a move to new quarters. The postscript mentions the reaction of the popular press and the medical journals to the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from [Louise Young Kean] and Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 18, 1900
div1.p:
You must forgive
me for having letter
a week pass without
writing to you for I
have been so busy I
have scarcely had
time to breathe. To
begin with was our
card party on Tuesday,
a hop on Wednesday,
and moving on Wednes-
day too, the Gen. came
to dinner Friday and
yesterday we went to
town to see the dear
old General off. It
was a sad day for
us all, as you can
imagine, and I think
the General felt very
blue too, over the break-
ing up of his staff
and leaving Cuba for
good.

But to go back to
the card party. Mrs.
Stark and I worked
like slaves for three
days, and were reward-
ed by having the
party a great success. To begin
with the piazza of the Starks cot-
tage was nearly all enclosed with
tent flys, and we had five card
tables out there and one in the
parlor. The party was from half
past three to six for neither of
us would upset the children by
having an evening affair. The house
was really beautiful decorated with-
in and without with palms and
roses and those bright foliage plants
from the palace. About fifty people
came and as each one arrived they
were given a mint julep. Mrs. Stark
said that was the way they
did in Norfolk, and it seemed to
work very well in Cuba. Then they
were put to playing six handed
euchre, but that did not last
very long for we had to begin
serving tea promptly at five to
get it in before dark. We fed them
2
well on creamed chicken
and mushrooms, baked
in little Cuban bowls,
Saratoga chips, lobster
salad, deviled ham &
lettuce sandwiches, olives
salted almonds, hot
chocolate, cold punch
(claret) and pineapple
ice served with those
crispy Cuban “horns” they
give you in the cafe's.
Mrs. Jackson won the
ladies' first prize, a
palm in a red water
jar, Capt. Sickle's the
gentlemen's, a box of
Henry Clays, and Mr.
Day the booby prize, a
little mule that walked
across the floor kicking.
Everybody seems to
have had a splendid
time, and Mrs. Stark
and I are sure the
“eatings” were the best
and the party the
jolliest that has ever
been given here. That
afternoon Martha and
the Stark boys had a
“card party” at my house
in which the little
freezer played a prominent
part.

The next day I moved from the cottage
into the row and I am not yet
entirely settled into my three rooms,
for tho' I brought so little down
with me and Rannie seemed to
have very little in his room the
whole face of the earth is covered
with our stuff. And I have the
prospect of another move in about
six weeks, when Dr. Havard comes
back and Rannie is made post
surgeon here.

Our party was Wednesday and the
hop in honor of the General Thursday
night. The pavilion was decorated
with the palms from Mrs. Starks, and
there was a big crowd for it was
the first dance in nearly six months
and the people came from Vedado
and Cabaña. No Cubanos tho'.

Mrs. Dun and Mrs. Slocum arrived
last Monday, so our house is full
and Mrs. Dun is running the
3
mess with her ser-
vants she brought from
the north. She is
a very nice little
woman, a sister of
Dalzell theof Gale base
ball fame, and she
knew Tom at New Haven.
We are sad at the
prospect of losing the
Duns in a few days,
for they are going to
move to Quemados
into the House of
the Lions, you remem-
ber it, don't you? Then
I will keep house with
Rufinia, for Mrs. Slocum
is so deaf she can't,
but she says she will
teach Rufinia to cook
lots of things. I knew
Mrs. S. and I would
get on finely together
and we are great
cronies already. While
I am devoted to Capt.
Slocum, he is so sweet
to me. (You needn't
tell Helen and Caz.)

Lots of people turned
out to see the General
Major Michie and Mrs.
Mc Cormick off on the
Morro Castle yesterday.
The band went down
too and played vigorously all the
time. I drove down from Coacha with
the General and he had a beau-
tiful, enormous bunch of roses for
me. We all went on board the
Morro Castle, which seems to be a
very fine steamer, and then the
General stood in the gangway and
said goodbye to each of us as we
went off. I know I nearly cried
and I think from the looks of the
ex. staff when they got back on
the Baker they all felt as I did. Mr.
Day, Mr. Rhea and Mr. Conrad all
go up on the Mc Pherson Monday.
Mr. Rhea has a six weeks leave
and Mr. Humphrey is just back
from one. He told me he left the
family very well and he has come
to see Bobbie so as to report on him,
as he was ordered to do.

I wish you could see your Bobs, he
is the very picture of health and
4
smiles at everybody
that speaks to him.
He never cries, except
yesterday, when I
took him out of his
bath sooner than he
wished me to, so
he scolded and cried
all the time I was
dressing him and
stopped as soon as I
gave him to Emma.

I am so sorry Peg
did not get to Augusta
she must have been
dreadfully disappointed.
Did any of you go to
Mrs. Twombly's dance?
Was it a costume affair?

I go down today to take
Col. Havards office and
Louise has opened one
eye to tell me to finish
her letter to you and put
it in the mail. From
the present length of it I
dont think it needs much
finishing. I was very glad
to get your letter the day
before yesterday, and to
hear your opinion as regard
the latest theory concerning
the “pestilence that flyest
by night.” Reed and I have
taken great enjoyment out
of the airy & superior tone of the lay papers
with regard to the mosquito theory. The
medical journals on the contrary treat
it with much consideration. Did you
see the N. Y. Herald's editorial? Well
in a couple of months I hope Reed
will show them how much they dont
know. We are still very much in the
air as regards our quarters & status
generally. I am at the present the proud
possessor of a barouche & pair of
blocks but fear to lose them any day.
Goodbye dear gran.
